solution_line_template: Earl will have ${earl_initial_money} - ${earl_owes_fred} = $<<{earl_initial_money}-{earl_owes_fred}={earl_after_paying_fred}>>{earl_after_paying_fred} after paying off his debt to Fred.
Fred will have ${fred_initial_money} + ${earl_owes_fred} = $<<{fred_initial_money}+{earl_owes_fred}={fred_after_earl_pays}>>{fred_after_earl_pays} after being paid by Earl.
But then Fred will have ${fred_after_earl_pays} - ${fred_owes_greg} = $<<{fred_after_earl_pays}-{fred_owes_greg}={fred_after_paying_greg}>>{fred_after_paying_greg} after paying Greg.
Greg will have ${greg_initial_money} + ${fred_owes_greg} = $<<{greg_initial_money}+{fred_owes_greg}={greg_after_fred_pays}>>{greg_after_fred_pays} after Fred paid him.
Then, Greg will have ${greg_after_fred_pays} - ${greg_owes_earl} = $<<{greg_after_fred_pays}-{greg_owes_earl}={greg_after_paying_earl}>>{greg_after_paying_earl} after paying off his debt to Earl.
So together, Greg and Earl will have ${greg_after_paying_earl} + ${earl_final_money} = $<<{greg_after_paying_earl}+{earl_final_money}={total_greg_earl}>>{total_greg_earl}.
